availability.p: For internal use by the Faclair na Gàidhlig/DASG projects

note.p: This manuscript has been described as "the detritus of the Kilbride collection" (Black 2011). It consists of three components, all in Gaelic but distinct in in scribal hand, shape, genre, and subject-matter. These contain religious poetry (1); a fragment of the Ulster Cycle text, Caithréim Conghail Cláiringhnigh (2); and a contract issued by Duncan MacDougall (1603×1616) (3). All are acephelous and suffer from various other sorts of damage, which is often serious.

summary.p: NLS Adv. 72.1.31, as currently bound, begins with a collection of poetry that is either about Colum Cille or attributed to him here or in other manuscripts. The latter type includes dramatic monologues set in the context of his hagiography and general pronouncements on religious themes. There is noticeable overlap in content between this collection and that in Laud Misc. 615, for which see Herbert and Sullivan (1973). Many of the poems are badly affected by erosion or loss of segments of vellum. Only four out of the thirteen poems catalogued by Black (2011) are sufficiently complete for meaningful transcription and even these transcriptions are based partially on edititions made of the poems from Laud Misc. 615.

The fragment of Caithréim Conghail Cláirignigh (for which, see MacSweeney (1904)) relates the Ulster king's voyage to Lochlann and his return to Ireland via Britain, together with the transactions he undertakes with various kings along the route. The text is in the expansive, prosimetric style of later Middle Irish narrative, with hints of later romances in the prominence of voyges to far-flung lands and magic in its narrative. Fol. 6 is in generally good condition but large swathes of fol. 7 appear illegible.

The MacDougall Contract seems to have been issued by Duncan MacDougall of Dunollie sometime between 1603 and 1616 (Black 1984: 143). Like the rest of the manuscript, it has suffered damage which obscures its details. However, it Black has argued from what is left that it concerns a tenant of MacDougall's (also called Duncan), who holds land from him in steelbow and is setting a portion of this land to a sub-tenant. The beginning of the text is lost, and most lines lack their own beginnings and ends, but substantial detail of the agreement is prserved nonetheless.

msItem.title: Offerings
msItem.explicit: ... { ar do dhe uad fein urbairt }

msItem.title: Heaven and Hell
msItem.explicit: ... an taigh ríg nimhi gan mairg

msItem.title: A Metrical Life of Colum Cille
Fragment of Caithréim Conghail Clairinghigh
msItem.incipit: Is maith linn catair Muirne d’faicsin ...

filiation.p: No other copies of this contract are known.

note.p: Black (0020336) suggests that this might alternatively be a verbal noun of aingid, producing the meaning "the servant is responsible for defending Donnchadh in night's-portion". However, a verbal noun in this form is not attested elsewhere, so this reading is not being adopted.
Black later proposes a full reading of this sentence (for which, see Slip 0020336).
